statement.p: Each system of linear equations is in echelon form (that is, the corresponding matrix is in echelon form). For each, say whether the system has a unique solution, no solution, or infinitely many solutions.

answer.p: If a system has a contradictory equation then it has no solution. Otherwise, if there are any variables that are not leading a row, then it has infinitely many solutions. In the final case, where there is no contradictory equation and every variable leads some row, it has a unique solution.

True or false: a system with more unknowns than equations has at least one solution. (To say true you must explain why it is always true without exception, while to say false you must produce a counterexample.)

answer.p: Recall that if a pair of lines share two distinct points then they are the same line. That's because two points determine a line, so these two points determine each of the two lines, and so they are the same line.
Thus the lines can share one point (giving a unique solution), share no points (giving no solutions), or share at least two points (which makes them the same line).

statement.p: (Howard Anton, Elementary Linear Algebra, John Wiley Sons, 1987) A box holding pennies, nickels and dimes contains thirteen coins with a total value of 83 cents. How many coins of each type are in the box? (These are US coins; a penny is 1 cent, a nickel is 5 cents, and a dime is 10 cents.)
